questions.text: Study the management technique given in the diagram. Identify the technique and find out the critical path. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.correct_answer: A. Network analysis and machinery installed
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Network analysis and machinery installed

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Network analysis consists of two components:
  • ➤ PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) - Shows sequence of activities
  • ➤ PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) - Shows sequence of activities
  • ➤ PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique)
  • ➤ CPM (Critical Path Method) - Identifies the longest duration path in the network
  • ➤ CPM (Critical Path Method)

questions.text: What is the maximum score that can be achieved in the New Ballard Score? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The New Ballard Score (also called the Expanded New Ballard Score) is a clinical assessment tool used to determine gestational age in newborns. It evaluates both neuromuscular and physical maturity criteria. The score consists of six neuromuscular criteria (posture, square window, arm recoil, popliteal angle, scarf sign, and heel to ear) and six physical maturity criteria (skin, lanugo, plantar surface, breast, eye/ear, and genitalia). A total possible range is from -10 to +50 points. Thus, the maximum achievable score is 50, which corresponds to a gestational age of approximately 44 weeks.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 30 - Incorrect . This is below the maximum possible score. A score of 30 would correspond to a gestational age of approximately 36-38 weeks.
  • • Option A. 30 - Incorrect
  • • Option B. 40 - Incorrect . This is below the maximum possible score. A score of 40 would correspond to a gestational age of approximately 40-42 weeks.
  • • Option B. 40 - Incorrect
  • • Option D. 60 - Incorrect . This exceeds the maximum possible score for the New Ballard Score. The highest possible score is 50 points.
  • • Option D. 60 - Incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The New Ballard Score has a maximum value of 50 points, which corresponds to a post-term infant of approximately 44 weeks gestational age. This scoring system allows for assessment of premature infants as young as 20 weeks gestational age (score of -10).

questions.text: Analyze the pedigree provided. Which mode of inheritance does it suggest? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mitochondrial inheritance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by maternal transmission only. All children of affected mothers inherit the condition, whereas no children of affected fathers are affected, due to the exclusive maternal origin of mitochondrial DNA. Both males and females may be affected, but only females pass on the trait.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition from the given graph. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Competitive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In competitive inhibition, the Lineweaver-Burk plot shows lines that cross at the y-axis, indicating that Vmax remains unchanged while Km increases due to the competition between the inhibitor and the substrate for the enzyme's active site.

questions.text: What is the preferred site for bone marrow aspiration in infants? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.correct_answer: C. Upper end of the tibia
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The preferred site for bone marrow aspiration in infants is the upper end (proximal portion) of the tibia, specifically the anteromedial surface of the proximal tibial metaphysis, approximately 1-2 cm below the tibial tuberosity. This site is preferred in infants because:
  • • It is easily accessible and has minimal overlying soft tissue The cortex is relatively thin, making penetration easier It is distant from vital structures like the heart and lungs The proximal tibial growth plate does not close until later in childhood It allows stable positioning of the infant during the procedure
  • • It is easily accessible and has minimal overlying soft tissue
  • • The cortex is relatively thin, making penetration easier
  • • It is distant from vital structures like the heart and lungs
  • • The proximal tibial growth plate does not close until later in childhood
  • • It allows stable positioning of the infant during the procedure
  • • In infants under 12-18 months of age, the tibial marrow cavity is still highly cellular and provides adequate samples for diagnostic purposes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Sternum - Incorrect. The sternum is not recommended as a site for bone marrow aspiration in infants due to the risk of serious complications, particularly cardiac or great vessel puncture. The sternum is too thin in infants and the proximity to vital structures makes this site dangerous.
  • • Option A. Sternum
  • • Option B. Spinous process of lumbar vertebra - Incorrect. The spinous processes of vertebrae are not used for bone marrow aspiration at any age. This site would be both technically difficult and dangerous due to proximity to the spinal cord.
  • • Option B. Spinous process of lumbar vertebra
  • • Option D. Lower end of femur - Incorrect. While the distal femur can be used as an alternative site for bone marrow aspiration in infants, it is not the preferred first-line site. The proximal tibia offers better access and is generally easier to perform.
  • • Option D. Lower end of femur

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The upper end of the tibia is the preferred site for bone marrow aspiration in infants under 12-18 months of age due to its accessibility, thinner cortex, distance from vital structures, and adequate cellularity.

questions.text: Following an accident, a patient presented with an inability to flex the MCP joint and extend the IP joint of his hand. Which nerve is damaged here? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ulnar nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ulnar nerve is responsible for innervating the third and fourth lumbricals, which are essential for flexing the MCP joints and extending the IP joints. Damage to this nerve can lead to the characteristic "claw hand" deformity.

questions.text: According to the Lund-Browder Chart, which body region's surface area percentage remains constant across all age groups? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Lund-Browder chart is used to calculate the percentage of total body surface area (TBSA) involved in burns and is specifically modified for children to account for the changing body proportions with age. According to this chart, the arm (including both anterior and posterior surfaces) consistently accounts for 9% of the total body surface area regardless of age. This percentage remains constant from birth through adulthood, making it a stable reference point when calculating burn surface area across different age groups.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Head - Incorrect . The head's surface area percentage changes dramatically with age. It accounts for approximately 19% of TBSA in infants but decreases to about 9% in adults as the body grows and proportions change.
  • • Option A. Head - Incorrect
  • • Option B. Thigh - Incorrect . The thigh's surface area percentage increases with age. In infants, each thigh (anterior and posterior together) accounts for about 5.5% of TBSA, which increases to about 9.5% in adults.
  • • Option B. Thigh - Incorrect
  • • Option C. Leg - Incorrect . The leg's surface area percentage also changes with age, increasing slightly from infancy (5%) to adulthood (7%) as the lower extremities become proportionally longer.
  • • Option C. Leg - Incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When using the Lund-Browder chart for burn assessment in pediatric patients, the arm surface area remains constant at 9% throughout all age groups, while head and lower extremity percentages change significantly with age.

questions.text: A patient presents with infection of the cavernous sinus with involvement of the nerve related on its medial side. To confirm the involvement of the abducent nerve, the patient is asked to look towards: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lateral side

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The abducent nerve (Cranial Nerve VI) controls the lateral rectus muscle, which moves the eye laterally. Damage to this nerve results in the inability to move the eye outward, leading to a medial squint (esotropia).
  • ➤ Mnemonic – EOM3 SO4 LR6 (all extraocular muscle are supplied by 3 rd CN except Superior oblique which is supplied by 4 th CN and lateral rectus muscle which is supplied by 6 th cranial nerve)
  • ➤ Mnemonic

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT used to diagnose Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE)? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare, progressive, and fatal neurological complication of measles infection that typically occurs 7-13 years after the primary infection. The diagnosis of SSPE is based on clinical features and supporting laboratory findings, and brain biopsy can show histopathological features of SSPE (such as demyelination, gliosis, and intranuclear inclusion bodies), it is:
  • • Invasive Rarely required Not part of the routine diagnostic workup, due to reliable clinical and laboratory alternatives.
  • • Invasive
  • • Rarely required
  • • Not part of the routine diagnostic workup, due to reliable clinical and laboratory alternatives.
  • • Dyken's Diagnostic Criteria for SSPE
  • • Major Criteria (Need at least 3 for diagnosis):
  • • Characteristic Clinical History and Presentation Progressive cognitive decline (e.g., intellectual deterioration) Behavioral changes Myoclonic jerks (often bilateral and symmetric) Motor dysfunction or seizures Characteristic EEG Findings Periodic, stereotyped, high-voltage discharges occurring every 4–10 seconds (often called "periodic complexes") Elevated Measles Antibody Titer in CSF Significantly elevated titers of measles-specific antibodies in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), usually disproportionately high compared to serum Elevated Measles Antibody Titer in Serum Measles IgG antibody titer in serum, often >1:256 or equivalent by ELISA Brain Biopsy or Histopathology Evidence of panencephalitis with demyelination, inclusion bodies, and gliosis on biopsy or autopsy (usually reserved for unclear cases) Minor Criteria (Supportive, but not required): History of primary measles infection, usually before 2 years of age Presence of oligoclonal bands in CSF Imaging findings (MRI) showing white matter lesions Progressive neurological decline over months to years Response to certain therapies (e.g., intraventricular interferon, isoprinosine)
  • • Characteristic Clinical History and Presentation Progressive cognitive decline (e.g., intellectual deterioration) Behavioral changes Myoclonic jerks (often bilateral and symmetric) Motor dysfunction or seizures
  • • Progressive cognitive decline (e.g., intellectual deterioration) Behavioral changes Myoclonic jerks (often bilateral and symmetric) Motor dysfunction or seizures
  • • Progressive cognitive decline (e.g., intellectual deterioration)
  • • Behavioral changes
  • • Myoclonic jerks (often bilateral and symmetric)
  • • Motor dysfunction or seizures
  • • Characteristic EEG Findings Periodic, stereotyped, high-voltage discharges occurring every 4–10 seconds (often called "periodic complexes")
  • • Periodic, stereotyped, high-voltage discharges occurring every 4–10 seconds (often called "periodic complexes")
  • • Periodic, stereotyped, high-voltage discharges occurring every 4–10 seconds (often called "periodic complexes")
  • • Elevated Measles Antibody Titer in CSF Significantly elevated titers of measles-specific antibodies in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), usually disproportionately high compared to serum
  • • Significantly elevated titers of measles-specific antibodies in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), usually disproportionately high compared to serum
  • • Significantly elevated titers of measles-specific antibodies in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), usually disproportionately high compared to serum
  • • Elevated Measles Antibody Titer in Serum Measles IgG antibody titer in serum, often >1:256 or equivalent by ELISA
  • • Measles IgG antibody titer in serum, often >1:256 or equivalent by ELISA
  • • Measles IgG antibody titer in serum, often >1:256 or equivalent by ELISA
  • • Brain Biopsy or Histopathology Evidence of panencephalitis with demyelination, inclusion bodies, and gliosis on biopsy or autopsy (usually reserved for unclear cases) Minor Criteria (Supportive, but not required): History of primary measles infection, usually before 2 years of age Presence of oligoclonal bands in CSF Imaging findings (MRI) showing white matter lesions Progressive neurological decline over months to years Response to certain therapies (e.g., intraventricular interferon, isoprinosine)
  • • Evidence of panencephalitis with demyelination, inclusion bodies, and gliosis on biopsy or autopsy (usually reserved for unclear cases) Minor Criteria (Supportive, but not required): History of primary measles infection, usually before 2 years of age Presence of oligoclonal bands in CSF Imaging findings (MRI) showing white matter lesions Progressive neurological decline over months to years Response to certain therapies (e.g., intraventricular interferon, isoprinosine)
  • • Evidence of panencephalitis with demyelination, inclusion bodies, and gliosis on biopsy or autopsy (usually reserved for unclear cases)
  • • Minor Criteria (Supportive, but not required): History of primary measles infection, usually before 2 years of age Presence of oligoclonal bands in CSF Imaging findings (MRI) showing white matter lesions Progressive neurological decline over months to years Response to certain therapies (e.g., intraventricular interferon, isoprinosine)
  • • History of primary measles infection, usually before 2 years of age Presence of oligoclonal bands in CSF Imaging findings (MRI) showing white matter lesions Progressive neurological decline over months to years Response to certain therapies (e.g., intraventricular interferon, isoprinosine)
  • • History of primary measles infection, usually before 2 years of age
  • • Presence of oligoclonal bands in CSF
  • • Imaging findings (MRI) showing white matter lesions
  • • Progressive neurological decline over months to years
  • • Response to certain therapies (e.g., intraventricular interferon, isoprinosine)
  • • Summary :
  • • Summary
  • • Diagnosis is typically confirmed if at least 3 of the 5 major criteria are fulfilled, especially with the clinical triad, EEG, and elevated CSF antibodies.
  • • Brain biopsy is invasive and rarely needed since the diagnosis can be reliably established with less invasive methods mentioned above.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. EEG - Incorrect . EEG is a crucial diagnostic tool for SSPE. It typically shows a characteristic pattern with periodic high-amplitude slow-wave complexes that occur every 4-10 seconds, known as Radermecker complexes.
  • • Option A. EEG - Incorrect
  • • Option C. Antibody in CSF - Incorrect . Elevated measles-specific antibodies in CSF are a key diagnostic criterion for SSPE. The CSF shows increased immunoglobulin G (IgG) with oligoclonal bands specific for measles virus.
  • • Option C. Antibody in CSF - Incorrect
  • • Option D. Antibody in blood - Incorrect . Elevated serum measles antibody titers (typically 1:256 or higher) are an important diagnostic feature of SSPE, reflecting the immune response to persistent measles virus infection.
  • • Option D. Antibody in blood - Incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SSPE diagnosis relies on clinical features, characteristic EEG patterns, and elevated measles antibodies in both CSF and serum, with brain biopsy being unnecessary for routine diagnosis of this measles complication.

questions.text: Among the following, which is the least common opportunistic fungus known to cause pulmonary infections in children? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Sporothrix is the least common opportunistic fungus among the given options to cause pulmonary infections in children. Sporothrix schenckii primarily causes sporotrichosis, which is typically a cutaneous infection that follows traumatic inoculation of the fungus into the skin, often through rose thorns or splinters (hence its nickname "rose gardener's disease"). Pulmonary sporotrichosis is extremely rare, especially in children, and is not typically considered among the common opportunistic pulmonary fungal infections.
  • • The other listed fungi are more commonly associated with pulmonary infections in immunocompromised children:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Aspergillus fumigatus - Incorrect . Aspergillus is a common cause of opportunistic pulmonary infections in immunocompromised children, especially those with prolonged neutropenia, chronic granulomatous disease, or those on long-term corticosteroid therapy. It can cause invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, and aspergilloma.
  • • Option A. Aspergillus fumigatus - Incorrect
  • • Option B. Cryptococcus - Incorrect . Cryptococcus (particularly C. neoformans) is a significant cause of pulmonary and central nervous system infections in immunocompromised children, especially those with HIV/AIDS or on immunosuppressive therapy. Pulmonary cryptococcosis is more common than pulmonary sporotrichosis.
  • • Option B. Cryptococcus - Incorrect
  • • Option D. Mucor - Incorrect . Mucor species (causing mucormycosis) are increasingly recognized as important opportunistic fungi in immunocompromised children, particularly those with diabetic ketoacidosis, prolonged neutropenia, or those receiving deferoxamine therapy. Rhinocerebral and pulmonary mucormycosis are the most common clinical presentations.
  • • Option D. Mucor - Incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sporothrix schenckii primarily causes cutaneous sporotrichosis following traumatic inoculation and is rarely associated with pulmonary infections in children, unlike Aspergillus, Cryptococcus, and Mucor species, which are more common opportunistic pulmonary pathogens in immunocompromised pediatric patients.

questions.text: Name the joint formed between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Synchondrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The joint formed between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone during development is a synchondrosis, which is a primary cartilaginous joint composed of hyaline cartilage that eventually ossifies as growth completes.

questions.text: At what age does the kidney typically attain adult-level Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Birth - Incorrect . At birth, the GFR is only about 15-20% of adult values. The kidneys are still immature with limited filtration capacity, which is why newborns have limited ability to concentrate urine and excrete waste products.
  • • Option A. Birth - Incorrect
  • • Option C. 2-5 years - Incorrect . This is too late, as adult levels of GFR are already achieved by 1-2 years of age. By 2-5 years, kidney function has been at adult levels for some time.
  • • Option C. 2-5 years - Incorrect
  • • Option D. Puberty - Incorrect . This is much too late. Adult-level GFR is reached many years before puberty. At puberty, the kidneys have long been functioning at adult capacity in terms of filtration rate.
  • • Option D. Puberty - Incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Renal function matures rapidly during infancy, with GFR reaching adult levels by 1-2 years of age.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Phenylketonuria (PKU) is NOT true? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Excess Melanin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phenylketonuria results in decreased (not increased) melanin production, leading to characteristic features like fair skin, blonde hair and blue eyes due to reduced tyrosine availability for melanin synthesis.

questions.text: Anterior fontanelle closes at which age? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anterior fontanelle typically closes between 12 to 24 months of age, making this a key point for assessing normal infant development.

questions.text: Why is atropine mixed with diphenoxylate in combination medications? (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Atropine decreases the adverse effect of diphenoxylate

questions.correct_answer: B. To prevent abuse of diphenoxylate
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) To prevent abuse of diphenoxylate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atropine is added to diphenoxylate to prevent the abuse of the opioid component by causing unpleasant side effects if the medication is taken in large doses, thereby discouraging misuse.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines was withdrawn due to an increased risk of intussusception? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The first licensed rotavirus vaccine (RotaShield) was withdrawn from the market in 1999 due to an increased risk of intussusception. Intussusception is a condition where one segment of intestine telescopes into another segment, causing intestinal obstruction. The original RotaShield vaccine showed an association with intussusception at a rate of approximately 1 case per 10,000 vaccinated infants, with most cases occurring within 1 week of the first dose. This led to its voluntary withdrawal. Newer rotavirus vaccines (RotaTeq and Rotarix) were subsequently developed and have a much lower risk of intussusception (approximately 1-5 cases per 100,000 vaccinated infants).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. MMR (Measles, Mumps, and Rubella) - Incorrect. The MMR vaccine has never been withdrawn from the market. While it has faced controversy due to a now-retracted publication suggesting a link to autism, this claim has been thoroughly disproven by multiple large studies, and MMR remains an essential component of childhood immunization programs.
  • • Option A. MMR (Measles, Mumps, and Rubella)
  • • Option C. JE Vaccine (Japanese Encephalitis) - Incorrect. The JE vaccine has not been withdrawn due to intussusception. Some older versions had higher rates of adverse effects, but these were primarily allergic reactions, not intussusception.
  • • Option C. JE Vaccine (Japanese Encephalitis)
  • • Option D. Polio Vaccine - Incorrect. The oral polio vaccine (OPV) has been replaced by the inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) in many countries, but this was due to the rare risk of vaccine-associated paralytic poliomyelitis (VAPP), not intussusception.
  • • Option D. Polio Vaccine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The original rotavirus vaccine (RotaShield) was withdrawn due to an increased risk of intussusception.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use is admitted to the hospital. He presents with anxiety, tremors, and agitation after his last drink 24 hours ago. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for control of alcohol withdrawal symptoms? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lorazepam

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lorazepam is the most appropriate medication for managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms due to its CNS depressant effects and safety profile, particularly in patients with liver impairment.

questions.text: In a patient with a left-to-right shunt, the presence of pulmonary plethora, an enlarged left atrium, and a normal aorta suggests which of the following? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ventricular septal defect is characterized by pulmonary plethora, left atrial enlargement, and a normal or small aorta, which distinguishes it from other left-to-right shunts like ASD (which shows RA and RV enlargement) and PDA (which shows aortic enlargement).

questions.text: Which of the following factors is NOT associated with a substantially greater risk of developing epilepsy after febrile seizures? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.correct_answer: B. Family history of Febrile Seizure
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Family history of Febrile Seizure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While family history of febrile seizures increases the risk of recurrence of febrile seizures, it does not substantially increase the risk of developing epilepsy, unlike neurodevelopmental abnormalities, complex febrile seizures, or family history of epilepsy.

questions.text: Complete heart block in Neonatal Lupus is associated with which maternal autoantibodies? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Complete congenital heart block in neonatal lupus erythematosus (NLE) is strongly associated with maternal anti-Ro (SSA) antibodies. These autoantibodies cross the placenta during pregnancy and can affect the developing fetal cardiac conduction system, particularly the atrioventricular (AV) node. The maternal anti-Ro antibodies can cause inflammation and subsequent fibrosis of the fetal cardiac conduction system, resulting in complete heart block. The risk of developing congenital heart block is approximately 2% in anti-Ro positive mothers, but increases to about 15-20% if there is a previous child with neonatal lupus. Anti-La (SSB) antibodies often coexist with anti-Ro and may increase the risk.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Anti-RNP - Incorrect. While anti-RNP antibodies are found in mothers with mixed connective tissue disease and SLE, they are not specifically associated with congenital heart block in neonatal lupus.
  • • Option A. Anti-RNP
  • • Option C. Anti-ds-DNA - Incorrect. Anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies are highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus in mothers but are not the primary antibodies associated with congenital heart block in the fetus.
  • • Option C. Anti-ds-DNA
  • • Option D. Anti-Sm - Incorrect. Anti-Smith antibodies are highly specific for SLE diagnosis in mothers but are not specifically linked to congenital heart block in neonatal lupus.
  • • Option D. Anti-Sm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Maternal anti-Ro (SSA) antibodies are specifically associated with congenital complete heart block in neonatal lupus, requiring careful monitoring of the fetal heart rate during pregnancy in anti-Ro positive mothers, especially those with a previous affected child.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl, who showed normal development for the first year but now presents with developmental delay and stereotypic hand-wringing movements along with breath-holding spells, is most likely diagnosed with: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Rett's Syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder that almost exclusively affects females and has a characteristic clinical course. The hallmark of Rett's Syndrome is normal development during the first 6-18 months of life followed by developmental regression. The clinical features described in this case are classic for Rett's Syndrome, particularly:
  • • Initially normal development followed by regression Stereotypic hand movements, specifically hand-wringing (also described as "hand-washing" movements) Female gender (Rett's syndrome is almost exclusively seen in females)
  • • Initially normal development followed by regression
  • • Stereotypic hand movements, specifically hand-wringing (also described as "hand-washing" movements)
  • • Female gender (Rett's syndrome is almost exclusively seen in females)
  • • Rett's Syndrome is caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome. Additional features include acquired microcephaly, loss of purposeful hand movements, gait abnormalities, and seizures.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Autism - Incorrect. While autism also involves developmental issues, it typically does not follow a period of normal development with subsequent regression. The specific hand-wringing movements are characteristic of Rett's Syndrome rather than autism. Additionally, autism affects both genders, with a higher prevalence in males.
  • • Option B. Autism
  • • Option C. Asperger's Syndrome - Incorrect. Asperger's Syndrome is characterized by normal language development with social communication difficulties and restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior. It does not typically present with regression after normal development or the characteristic hand-wringing movements seen in Rett's Syndrome.
  • • Option C. Asperger's Syndrome
  • • Option D. Prader-Willi Syndrome - Incorrect. Prader-Willi Syndrome presents with hypotonia, poor feeding in infancy followed by hyperphagia (excessive eating), obesity, and intellectual disability. It does not typically include a period of normal development followed by regression or stereotypic hand movements.
  • • Option D. Prader-Willi Syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rett's Syndrome presents with normal early development (6-18 months) followed by regression, with characteristic stereotypic hand-wringing movements and is predominantly seen in females due to its X-linked dominant inheritance pattern.

questions.text: A child has Measles. He presents to OPD at PHC with red congestion of eyes, fever, and coryza. On examination, he has got Bitot spots. Management protocol for this child will be: (FMGE JAN 2025)

options.label: B
options.text: Isolation + Symptomatic treatment + Treat Vit-A deficiency

options.label: C
options.text: Give MR vaccine + Treat Vit-A deficiency + Treat Vit-A deficiency

options.label: D
options.text: Give aspirin for fever + Treat Vit-A deficiency

questions.correct_answer: B. Isolation + Symptomatic treatment + Treat Vit-A deficiency
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Isolation + Symptomatic treatment + Treat Vit-A deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Management of measles with concurrent Vitamin A deficiency are:
  • ➤ Isolation Symptomatic treatment Vitamin A supplementation
  • ➤ Isolation
  • ➤ Isolation
  • ➤ Symptomatic treatment
  • ➤ Symptomatic treatment
  • ➤ Vitamin A supplementation
  • ➤ Vitamin A supplementation

questions.text: Management of an HIV-positive patient with multiple punctured wound bites caused by a dog is: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.correct_answer: C. Rabies vaccine + Immunoglobulin + Wound management
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rabies vaccine + Immunoglobulin + Wound management

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Class III rabies exposure (multiple punctured wounds) requires complete post-exposure prophylaxis including:
  • ➤ Local wound management Rabies vaccine Rabies immunoglobulin regardless of patient's immune status.
  • ➤ Local wound management
  • ➤ Local wound management
  • ➤ Rabies vaccine
  • ➤ Rabies vaccine
  • ➤ Rabies immunoglobulin regardless of patient's immune status.
  • ➤ Rabies immunoglobulin regardless of patient's immune status.

questions.text: A tourist group was headed by a tour guide. They were seen many times in an area. Which kind of group dynamics does this represent? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Herd

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Ciclesonide is incorrect? (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Oral candidiasis is common with its use.

options.label: B
options.text: It has fewer side effects than other inhalational corticosteroids.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a prodrug activated by bronchial esterase.

options.label: D
options.text: It has comparable efficacy to other inhalational corticosteroids.

questions.correct_answer: A. Oral candidiasis is common with its use.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis is common with its use.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ciclesonide, a prodrug inhalational corticosteroid, has a lower risk of causing oral candidiasis compared to other inhalational steroids because it remains inactive until it reaches the lungs, where it is activated by bronchial esterases.
